item.title: Seafront Cycle Route
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: This is Alfie Perry -Ward last Sunday 14th March 2010. He and his Mum and Dad were delighted that Alfie can ride independently along the cycle route. They were proud to say that Alfie got his bikeability 2 award at a Portsmouth School. The future.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
Portsmouth Cycle Forum is an independent cycle campaign group in Portsmouth.We believe thatPortsmouth is a great place to live and to cycle. The city is flat, compact and the climate is warm. Were only a few miles from the South Downs and New Forest national parks and a short hop by ferry to the Isle of Wight. All of these offer fantastic riding with tangled masses of quiet lanes to explore. Portsmouth itself is one of the most densely populated places in the UK. It is also on an Island connected to the mainland by only 3 roads, making it very congested. This means that the rate of cycling in the city is low as many people feel that it is too dangerous. We areworking hard to change this. We're building close relationships with the city council to help them design schemes that really help cyclists. We are looking to cities like Bristol and, of course, Dutch cities like Groningen to learn from what they have achieved. Cycling is a great opportunity for Portsmouth to become a healthier, cleaner and more liveable city. The next step is to develop a strong cycling strategy and to focus on reducing cycle casualties. Once people feel safe they'll try cycling and I'm sure most will never look back. Portsmouth Cycle Forum welcomes individuals and representatives of organisations who are interested in cycling and related issues in the Portsmouth area.
  • We campaign for the improvement of safety, convenience and practicality of cycling.
  • We encourage discussion among those who influence cycling in Portsmouth and among others who may be affected by it.
  • We are interested in all aspects of cycling in Portsmouth.
We meet formally every two months at venues across the city. Please refer to the "Calendar" section for details of the next meeting. Our constitution is in the document liked at the bottom of this page. Between meetings a committee meets monthly and puts into effect the actions approved at the monthly meetings. To join Portsmouth Cycle Forum please download, print and complete a membership formor join online. The annual subscription for most members is 5.

Portsmouth Cycle Forum Constitution

The latest copy of our constitution is linked below in PDF format. PCF Constitution v2.2 For further details please get in touch by using the Contact Us" section.

Portsmouth Cycle Forum - working to make cycling safe, easy and fun

item.title: Contributor's Guide
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
This is a brief guide to making a contribution to the PompeyBUG website. There are 2 ways in which you can get your thoughts onto the website: Comments and Posts.

Comments

Anyone can make a comment on an existing article, providing that article is less than 2 weeks old. To make a comment you simply click the "Leave a Comment" link that appears at the bottom of each post. [caption id="attachment_474" align="alignnone" width="401" caption="The Comment Link"][/caption] Having clicked the link a form will appear for you to enter your name, email and the text of your comment. The first comment you make on the site will be held for moderation (this is a measure to avoid spam) but subsequent comments should appear straight away. When you post a comment you will be asked to provide a valid email address - this will not be visibly published on the site.

Posts

A post is a news story that appears on the main page of the PompeyBUG website. To write posts you will need an account on the website. All members of the PCF executive will automatically have accounts created for them - send a message via the 'contact us' page if there is a problem with yours. You can log into the site via the 'log in' link that appears on the very bottom right of the website. When you click on this link you will be asked to enter your username and password. When you have successfully entered these then you will see the 'Dashboard' page. There are a number of actions you can take on this page. To create a post click on 'Posts' on the left hand side and then 'Add New'. You will then be presented with the editor utility with which to write your post. There are a number of tools available for formatting, adding pictures and so on. Please associate your post to an appropriate category from the list on the right hand side. When you are happy with your post click the link to submit it for review on the right hand side. All posts must be approved by either John Holland or Jon Spencer before they appear.

item.title: Candidate Logos
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
Entries to the logo competition have now closed and you can see all of the candidate logos below. You can vote for your favourite by following this link.
Candidate Logos
Logo Notes
Designer - Ric Robinson The stylised bike logo that split opinion at the open meeting. This is a simple, clean design produced by a professional graphic artist (Ric Robinson). It represents a bike and the letters PCF with only 4 lines. Supporters liked the fact that it was stark, strong and unique with perhaps a Japanese feel Critics felt that it was too hard to see what it was and that it had communistic undertones.
Designer - Tristan Savage A clean, strong logo that will scale to all sizes to work well in all media - website, business cards, flyers etc. The logo has been designed to work in the simplest colour form (black) so that it will transfer across many colours and work in many different ways. Tristan has produced some examples of how his logo could be used in banners and on photographs. Have a look at them.
Designer - Jon Spencer A simple bike, skewed to give the impression of movement.
Designer - Jon Spencer A simple design taking the city's emblem of a star and crescent and putting them into the chainwheel and sprocket of a bicycle drive train.
Designer - Jon Spencer A variation on the star and crescent design with the star as a cut out.
Designer - Kathy Azopardi Text based logo with a cog on the O.
Note that Ric Robinson is not happy for his design to be modified - therefore any proposed logos must be based on original ideas rather than variations on Ric's. All designs that were variations on Ric's have been removed.

item.title: Tristan's Logo Designs
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
Hi guys,
I saw your call for a new PCF logo on my regular visit to your site today and thought it was a great opportunity to have a go and get involved with the local cycle community outside of riding.
I've attached 3 logo ideas and banners. The focus being on creating not just a visual logo, but a logo that also incorporates the Pompey Bug title whilst having an easily recognisable icon alongside it. The bike cog.
Each logo has been designed to work in it's simplest colour form, black. This means it will transfer across many colours and work in many different ways. I've attached a few photo examples of how they can be used in different ways.
They also work well when scaled down to a small size. This gives the logos a lot more scope outside of just being a website header. Business cards, stickers, letters etc
Really enjoyed doing them and I'll have a blast at a few more over the next few days. I've also attached copies of the logos by themselves.
P.S All the photos used in the headers are mine and therefore available to use royalty free alongside any any of the logos.
All the best.
Tristan

item.title: Campaigns
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
Portsmouth Cycle Forum is constantly campaigning for better cycling infrastructure in Portsmouth. Our current major campaigns are:
  • The Portsmouth Cycle Forum Manifesto is here.
  • Issue Tracking Database - Portsmouth Cycle Forum maintains a database of problems with cycling infrastructure in Portsmouth. To use the database follow this link: Issue Tracking Database.
  • Seafront Cycle Route - PCF supports the cycle route currently being installed between Eastney and South Parade Pier and is campaigning for phase 2 to be approved and installed. To read our Q&A on the seafront cycle route and to find out how to support the route go to our Seafront Cycle Route page.
  • Strategic Cycle Routes - PCF is campaigning for better North-South routes in and out of the city. Read our strategic cycle routes page.

item.title: Annual General Meeting 4 March
item.dc:creator: john holland
item.content:encoded: Portsmouth Cycle Forum will hold its annual general meeting at the open forum meeting on the 4th March. Elections will be held for the posts of Chairman, Vice-Chairman, Secretary, Treasurer, and 5 committee members. Any current members of the Cycle Forum may stand for election. If you are interested please contact the current committee by using the Contact page. Just as importantly, annual membership subscriptions are due for renewal at the modest fee of 5. This fee helps to pay running costs for the Forum including insurance for events and rides. The Treasurer will be taking subscriptions on the night! New members are always welcome. For a membership application form please see the About page. The meeting will take place in Room 1 on the 3rd floor of Portsmouth Guildhall starting at 7pm. Letter to members from the Treasurer

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] Annual General Meeting 4 March [...]

item.title: AGM - Letter to members
item.dc:creator: john holland
item.content:encoded: Dear Member Portsmouth Cycle Forum will hold our annual general meeting at the next open forum meeting on 4th March. Elections will be held for the following posts:- Chair, Vice-Chair, Secretary, Treasurer. Another 5 posts within the executive committee are also available. We aim to make the Forum as accountable and democratic as possible, and invite supporters to put themselves forward for these posts. Executive meetings are generally held once a month to discuss relevant and topical issues related to the Forum and cycling in general. They need not be onerous or time-consuming jobs only if you want them to be! Please reply by by using the contact form, if you wish to stand for any of these executive posts. If you have any questions, please contact a member of the current exec: [e.g. Roger Inkpen, Treasurer on 9264 7542]. We will also be voting on 2 changes to our constitution, to increase the size of the executive, and reduce the period of notice of AGM: 4.2 Additional [executive] members, to a maximum of six, shall be elected from the body of the Forum. 5.1 The committee shall be elected annually at the Annual General Meeting. 14 days notice must be given of this meeting. Just as importantly, annual membership subscriptions are due for renewal from April at the modest fee of 5. This fee helps to pay running costs for the Forum including insurance for events and rides. The Treasurer will be taking subscriptions on the night. Please note only current members may vote at this meeting although executive positions are available to anyone taking out membership for the coming year. Roger Inkpen, Treasurer, February 2010

item.title: Strategic Cycle Routes
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_385" align="alignright" width="252" caption="Strategic Cycle Routes"] [/caption] Portsmouth Cycle Forum, in partnership with the Cyclist Touring Club, delivered a report on the state of the major cycle routes in and out of Portsmouth in November 2009. The document provides an objective user's view of the key cycle routes in to and out of Portsmouth. It assesses their safety, their usability by all types of cyclist and how well they meet the Department for Transport (DfT) and Portsmouth City Council (PCC) aspirations for cycle infrastructure. PCC aspires to produce a cycle network interconnecting all locations in the city - good quality arterial routes in and out of the city are an essential element of any such network. This document provides a baseline to assist planning and development of Portsmouth's cycle network. The document is split into two sections - the main body which presents an overview and assessment of each route and appendices which provide detailed analysis of each route. Both are available for download:
  • Commentary on Strategic Cycle Routes in Portsmouth - Main Body (0.5 MB PDF)
  • Commentary on Strategic Cycle Routes in Portsmouth - Appendices (5.5 MB PDF)
  • Strategic Cycle Routes Presentation (6.5MB Powerpoint PPT)

item.title: Seafront Cycle Route
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
Support the SFCR Express your support for the seafront cycle route and your wish that phase 2 be approved and installed as soon as possible by clicking this link.
There has been a great deal of public debate about the Sea Front Cycle Route (SFCR), some of which has been based on incomplete information. Members of the Portsmouth Cycle Forum (PCF) have for a long time been advocates of the SFCR and are well placed to make an informed contribution to the discussion. Below are typical questions and our answers (Q&A).
Questions and Answers
Why does Portsmouth need the SFCR? 1. Portsmouth is part of the Healthy Towns initiative and the Change4Life programme and is working to improve levels of fitness and reduce obesity. Encouraging people to exercise including cycling instead of using their cars will contribute to our overall fitness and health. The new seafront cycle route will be a safe, attractive and enjoyable route for experienced and inexperienced cyclists, young and old and of all levels of fitness. It will therefore give a great opportunity for the residents of Portsmouth to build enjoyable exercise into their daily routines and to access the seafront in a new way. 2. Portsmouth is committed to a reduction of 30 per cent carbon emissions by 2015 in order to contribute to national targets to minimise the effects of climate change. In order to achieve this ambitious target many green environmental measures need to be introduced, one of which is to achieve a modal shift of traveller choice of mode of transport from the private motor car to sustainable transport buses, cycling and walking - and this modal shift will have the benefit of reducing road congestion. This has also been PCC policy for several years. The SFCR will make commuting easier along a key east-west route through the city. 3. The UK is criss-crossed by many routes in the National Cycle Network (NCN) promoted by the environmental charity Sustrans. NCN2 runs along the South Coast from Folkestone to Exeter but there are a few gaps, notably in Portsmouth. As Portsmouth City Council (PCC) policy documents frequently state Portsmouth is a flat and compact city ideally suited for cycling this incomplete section in Portsea Island is an embarrassing omission. Completing the SFCR (to extend from Eastney to the Gosport Ferry) has been a Council objective since at least 2004. These advantages are recognised in Portsmouths Second Local Transport Plan summary of measures to improve accessibility:

Promotion of cycle use as an alternative to car for work and school journeys has a positive impact on individuals, the local community, the environment and economy.

Why couldnt the council leave things unchanged? Much of the car parking along the sea front is echelon parking where cars drive in at an angle of about 45 degrees. Getting out is difficult for drivers because often they cant see what is coming and so they reverse almost blind into the traffic flow. The problems are increased with many of the parking spaces being shorter than the Department for Transport recommended length of 4.2 metres which means that vehicles stick out more into the vehicle lane. Reversing out is also dangerous for cyclists because drivers are even less likely to see cyclists than cars. Accidents happen periodically and there was a nasty accident in 2009 when a driver reversed into a cyclist who was knocked off his bike and was taken to Southampton with severe head injuries. Fortunately he recovered, but the incident demonstrated that echelon parking is inherently less safe than parallel parking where cars are parked parallel to the traffic flow (sideways on to the kerb or wall). Echelon parking requires people to stand in the busy highway to remove the push chairs etc. This is a danger to them and to passing traffic. With parallel parking it is safer for car occupants to remove things from the rear hatch/ boot. Why cant I sit in my car and look at the sea anymore? Very few old echelon spaces actually looked at the sea. Most faced the sea wall, stony beach, shrubs or Castle Field. Why cant cyclists use the promenade? One of the original options was to permit cycling on the promenade. This is already permitted by some 60 seaside local authorities around the UK such as Brighton, Bournemouth, Worthing and Blackpool. These successful promenade cycling schemes embrace the four Es of road safety strategy (Education, Engineering, Enforcement and Encouragement). A public consultation exercise was carried out in Portsmouth and it was reported in The News that there was a huge majority for the option for allowing cycling on the promenade, although PCC never released the results. However, it appears that the popular vote was overruled by some senior councillors reacting to safety concerns about cyclists using the same space as pedestrians. Whilst such concerns are valid, we believe that these risks could have been minimised using the four road safety Es reflecting best practice widespread in Europe and some UK towns. In our view the risks were greatly exaggerated by a vocal minority with people claiming to have seen accidents or near misses even though these accidents seemed never to be reported to the police or to the Council. The PCF has always argued for a SFCR whilst emphasising that it has to be a practical and safe route for all users cyclists, pedestrians and drivers. Individual members had their own preferences e.g. the promenade option would have appealed mostly to leisure cyclists and families, the separate cycle lane would have been preferred by commuters. Even so, we support PCC in recognising that the scheme being implemented is the best compromise in the circumstances. Are cyclists allowed to cycle on the promenade? No, the red circular No Cycling signs will remain. The PCF stands for observance of the Highway Code by all road users (cyclists, drivers and pedestrians) and once the SFCR provides a safe route along the entire seafront there should not be any excuse for cyclists to use the promenade (excepting maybe small children being accompanied by their pedestrian parents). If cycling is not allowed on the promenade why then do we see vehicles driving along it? Technically the promenade is classed as a Vehicle Restricted Area (VRA) and essential vehicles such as the emergency services are allowed access, and cleaning/maintenance vehicles are permitted to drive in VRAs if they hold the required permit from the Council. It is more difficult to vouch for the drivers of private motor cars being driven on the promenade. Echelon parked vehicles often overhang the promenade and encroach on space for pedestrians What will be the effect on seafront businesses? Once the SFCR has become well known we predict there will be a net benefit to seafront traders. It is one of the effects of the green pound. Some visitors to Portsmouth come by car and park on the seafront but when (or if) theyve paid for their parking they spend hardly any money because they come laden with their own sandwiches and thermos flasks. On the other hand, cyclists carry little food and water because of the weight and so are much more likely to buy food and drinks from seafront traders. One forward-thinking restaurant owner has offered a discount to cyclists! An increasing number of hotels, B & Bs and attractions welcome cyclists. They have agreed to provide and market themselves with secure cycle parking. Many of these have no on-street car parking yet can easily accommodate cycling business and tourist customers and their bicycles. Cycle parking requires one seventh of the space, and is easily provided off street. What do you say to the seafront being ruined by the SFCR? Ruined? We dont think so. The road layout changes arent affecting the promenade. More non-polluting cycling and fewer congestion-producing air-polluting cars will contribute to a quieter and cleaner seafront and so it will be better for everyone. How many car parking spaces have been lost? In the first phase of the scheme (Eastney Swimming Pool to South Parade Pier) about 144 spaces have been removed out of 511, overall a 28% reduction. However, surveys done in 2009 over the August Bank Holiday weekend with good weather and high numbers of visitors showed that on very few occasions were all parking spaces filled along the sea front. Almost all the time people will still be able to park, it might just be slightly further from the main attractions. However, as PCC wants people to walk more this might not be a bad thing. Disabled parking spaces will still be provided close to the main attractions. Suggestions have been made about providing more car parking close to the sea front. What is the cost of the scheme? Phase 1 will cost 138,000, provided by the Healthy Towns Access2cycling budget, the Local Transport Plan and the Section 106 Sustainable Transport fund. I was down there last week and didnt see anyone using the SFCR. Isnt it a waste of money? The SFCR is still under construction but even so is still being used a lot. Once Phase 1 is complete and word gets around we expect that it will become very popular. What about the dangers to drivers and their passengers opening their parked car doors with cars coming up behind them? Yes, drivers and their passengers will have to look behind them before opening car doors. However, they should do that anyway the Highway Code article 239 states

"you MUST ensure you do not hit anyone when you open your door. Check for cyclists or other traffic"

so this isnt anything new. Isnt there a danger to cyclists with passenger (nearside) doors being opened in their path? There is a plainly marked buffer zone/ refuge between the parking and the lane. When properly parked a fully open car door makes little or no intrusion into the cycle lane. Most cars will be parked facing west and occupants will face cyclists heading east. Cyclists will be better able to see car passengers. There is a low risk of a cyclist being hit by a car door. Overall we assess that the danger is less than being hit by a car reversing out of echelon parking. Isnt it dangerous for everyone when drivers have to cross the SFCR to get to the parking ticket machines? The Parking machines are more visible now. Drivers walk securely along the refuge area or the promenade until they reach the nearest machine. This is safer than before when drivers had to thread their way through echelon-parked cars until they discovered a ticket machine obscured by other parked cars We believe that PCC is considering installing new ticket machines and if these go on the mini traffic islands this should reduce the risks. Another mitigating safety factor is that it is possible to buy tickets from a mobile phone. Are cars allowed to drive or park on the cycle route? No. The Highway Code states in article 240:

"You MUST NOT stop or park on a cycle track"

Are cyclists obliged to stay off the road now theyve got a cycle route? No. The Highway Code does not require cyclists to use cycle facilities. Cyclists have as much right to use the main road as anyone else. Just as there are several different categories of driver (commuter, leisure, van, HGV etc) so the Department for Transport (DfT) recognises five different types of cyclist. The SFCR will encourage a lot of leisure cycling especially for families as it will make the seafront safer for children to cycle along. However, it is quite narrow for two-way cycling and some sport cyclists and fast commuter cyclists may feel that the road meets their particular needs better. We would, however, encourage them to at least try the new cycle lane before making that decision. Therefore drivers should expect to see some cyclists using the main road and drivers should only overtake cyclists only where safe to do so (see Highway Code articles 162, 212 and 213).

Why does Portsmouth need the SFCR?

1. Portsmouth is part of the Healthy Towns initiative and the Change4Life programme and is working to improve levels of fitness and reduce obesity. Encouraging people to exercise including cycling instead of using their cars will contribute to our overall fitness and health. The new seafront cycle route will be a safe, attractive and enjoyable route for experienced and inexperienced cyclists, young and old and of all levels of fitness. It will therefore give a great opportunity for the residents of Portsmouth to build enjoyable exercise into their daily routines and to access the seafront in a new way.

2. Portsmouth is committed to a reduction of 30 per cent carbon emissions by 2015 in order to contribute to national targets to minimise the effects of climate change. In order to achieve this ambitious target many green environmental measures need to be introduced, one of which is to achieve a modal shift of traveller choice of mode of transport from the private motor car to sustainable transport buses, cycling and walking - and this modal shift will have the benefit of reducing road congestion. This has also been PCC policy for several years. The SFCR will make commuting easier along a key east-west route through the city.

3. The UK is criss-crossed by many routes in the National Cycle Network (NCN) promoted by the environmental charity Sustrans. http://www.sustrans.org.uk/what-we-do/national-cycle-network NCN2 runs along the South Coast from Folkestone to Exeter but there are a few gaps, notably in Portsmouth. As Portsmouth City Council (PCC) policy documents frequently state Portsmouth is a flat and compact city ideally suited for cycling this incomplete section in Portsea Island is an embarrassing omission. Completing the SFCR (to extend from Eastney to the Gosport Ferry) has been a Council objective since at least 2004.

These advantages are recognised in Portsmouths Second Local Transport Plan summary of measures to improve accessibility:

Promotion of cycle use as an alternative to car for work and school journeys has a positive impact on individuals, the local community, the environment and economy.

Why couldnt the council leave things unchanged?

Much of the car parking along the sea front is echelon parking where cars drive in at an angle of about 45 degrees. Getting out is difficult for drivers because often they cant see what is coming and so they reverse almost blind into the traffic flow. The problems are increased with many of the parking spaces being shorter than the Department for Transport recommended length of 4.2 metres which means that vehicles stick out more into the vehicle lane. Reversing out is also dangerous for cyclists because drivers are even less likely to see cyclists than cars. Accidents happen periodically and there was a nasty accident in 2009 when a driver reversed into a cyclist who was knocked off his bike and was taken to Southampton with severe head injuries. Fortunately he recovered, but the incident demonstrated that echelon parking is inherently less safe than parallel parking where cars are parked parallel to the traffic flow (sideways on to the kerb or wall).

Echelon parking requires people to stand in the busy highway to remove the push chairs etc. This is a danger to them and to passing traffic. With parallel parking it is safer for car occupants to remove things from the rear hatch/ boot.

Why cant I sit in my car and look at the sea anymore?

Very few old echelon spaces actually looked at the sea. Most faced the sea wall, stony beach, shrubs or Castle Field.

Why cant cyclists use the promenade?

One of the original options was to permit cycling on the promenade. This is already permitted by some 60 seaside local authorities around the UK such as Brighton, Bournemouth, Worthing and Blackpool. These successful promenade cycling schemes embrace the four Es of road safety strategy (Education, Engineering, Enforcement and Encouragement).

A public consultation exercise was carried out in Portsmouth and it was reported in The News that there was a huge majority for the option for allowing cycling on the promenade, although PCC never released the results. However, it appears that the popular vote was overruled by some senior councillors reacting to safety concerns about cyclists using the same space as pedestrians. Whilst such concerns are valid, we believe that these risks could have been minimised using the four road safety Es reflecting best practice widespread in Europe and some UK towns. In our view the risks were greatly exaggerated by a vocal minority with people claiming to have seen accidents or near misses even though these accidents seemed never to be reported to the police or to the Council.

The PCF has always argued for a SFCR whilst emphasising that it has to be a practical and safe route for all users cyclists, pedestrians and drivers. Individual members had their own preferences e.g. the promenade option would have appealed mostly to leisure cyclists and families, the separate cycle lane would have been preferred by commuters. Even so, we support PCC in recognising that the scheme being implemented is the best compromise in the circumstances.

Are cyclists allowed to cycle on the promenade?

No, the red circular No Cycling signs will remain. The PCF stands for observance of the Highway Code by all road users (cyclists, drivers and pedestrians) and once the SFCR provides a safe route along the entire seafront there should not be any excuse for cyclists to use the promenade (excepting maybe small children being accompanied by their pedestrian parents).

If cycling is not allowed on the promenade why then do we see vehicles driving along it?

Technically the promenade is classed as a Vehicle Restricted Area (VRA) and essential vehicles such as the emergency services are allowed access, and cleaning/maintenance vehicles are permitted to drive in VRAs if they hold the required permit from the Council. It is more difficult to vouch for the drivers of private motor cars being driven on the promenade.

Echelon parked vehicles often overhang the promenade and encroach on space for pedestrians.

What will be the effect on seafront businesses?

Once the SFCR has become well known we predict there will be a net benefit to seafront traders. It is one of the effects of the green pound. Some visitors to Portsmouth come by car and park on the seafront but when (or if) theyve paid for their parking they spend hardly any money because they come laden with their own sandwiches and thermos flasks. On the other hand, cyclists carry little food and water because of the weight and so are much more likely to buy food and drinks from seafront traders. One forward-thinking restaurant owner has offered a discount to cyclists!

An increasing number of hotels, B & Bs and attractions welcome cyclists. They have agreed to provide and market themselves with secure cycle parking. Many of these have no on-street car parking yet can easily accommodate cycling business and tourist customers and their bicycles. Cycle parking requires one seventh of the space, and is easily provided off street.

What do you say to the seafront being ruined by the SFCR?

Ruined? We dont think so. The road layout changes arent affecting the promenade. More non-polluting cycling and fewer congestion-producing air-polluting cars will contribute to a quieter and cleaner seafront and so it will be better for everyone.

How many car parking spaces have been lost?

In the first phase of the scheme (Eastney Swimming Pool to South Parade Pier) about 144 spaces have been removed out of 511, overall a 28% reduction. However, surveys done in 2009 over the August Bank Holiday weekend with good weather and high numbers of visitors showed that on very few occasions were all parking spaces filled along the sea front. Almost all the time people will still be able to park, it might just be slightly further from the main attractions. However, as PCC wants people to walk more this might not be a bad thing. Disabled parking spaces will still be provided close to the main attractions. Suggestions have been made about providing more car parking close to the sea front.

What is the cost of the scheme?

Phase 1 will cost 138,000, provided by the Healthy Towns Access2cycling budget, the Local Transport Plan and the Section 106 Sustainable Transport fund.

I was down there last week and didnt see anyone using the SFCR. Isnt it a waste of money?

The SFCR is still under construction but even so is still being used a lot. Once Phase 1 is complete and word gets around we expect that it will become very popular.

What about the dangers to drivers and their passengers opening their parked car doors with cars coming up behind them?

Yes, drivers and their passengers will have to look behind them before opening car doors. However, they should do that anyway the Highway Code article 239 states

  • you MUST ensure you do not hit anyone when you open your door. Check for cyclists or other traffic

so this isnt anything new.

Isnt there a danger to cyclists with passenger (nearside) doors being opened in their path?

There is a plainly marked buffer zone/ refuge between the parking and the lane. When properly parked a fully open car door makes little or no intrusion into the cycle lane.

Most cars will be parked facing west and occupants will face cyclists heading east. Cyclists will be better able to see car passengers. There is a low risk of a cyclist being hit by a car door. Overall we assess that the danger is less than being hit by a car reversing out of echelon parking.

Isnt it dangerous for everyone when drivers have to cross the SFCR to get to the parking ticket machines?

The Parking machines are more visible now. Drivers walk securely along the refuge area or the promenade until they reach the nearest machine. This is safer than before when drivers had to thread their way through echelon-parked cars until they discovered a ticket machine obscured by other parked cars.

We believe that PCC is considering installing new ticket machines and if these go on the mini traffic islands this should reduce the risks. Another mitigating safety factor is that it is possible to buy tickets from a mobile phone.

Are cars allowed to drive or park on the cycle route?

No. The Highway Code states in article 240

  • You MUST NOT stop or park on a cycle track

Are cyclists obliged to stay off the road now theyve got a cycle route?

No. The Highway Code does not require cyclists to use cycle facilities, recognising that quite often cycle facilities do not meet national standards for cycle routes and so do not always provide the levels of convenience, accessibility and safety needed. Cyclists have as much right to use the main road as anyone else. Just as there are several different categories of driver (commuter, leisure, van, HGV etc) so the Department for Transport (DfT) recognises five different types of cyclist. The SFCR will encourage a lot of leisure cycling especially for families as it will make the seafront safer for children to cycle along. However, it is quite narrow for two-way cycling and some sport cyclists and fast commuter cyclists may feel that the road meets their particular needs better. We would, however, encourage them to at least try the new cycle lane before making that decision. Therefore drivers should expect to see some cyclists using the main road and drivers should only overtake cyclists only where safe to do so (see Highway Code articles 162, 212 and 213).

item.title: Flyer Design
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
I have worked up some flyer designs based on the outcome of the publicity meeting held on 14th June 2010. On the back will be a contact form, something like: I have worked up production copies of these designs on a sheet of A3 (all 6 designs are on one page) with bleed and crop marks ready for printing. If anyone fancies getting that done then the print ready files can be downloaded in a zip from here (caution, 45 megabyte download). Note that there are two files in the zip:
  • One in RGB colour. This is optimised for on-screen display and the file is called 'DL-Flyer-2010-RGB.pdf'.
  • One in CMYK colour. This is optimised for print and the file is called 'DL-Flyer-2010-CMYK-spotprocess.pdf'.
Each of these files contains 2 pages - page one contains the six different colour front images and page 2 contains six black and white backs (to save cost). They should line up perfectly when printed ready to be cut out. It is best to talk to the print company to see which they prefer - they may prefer to do the RGB-CMYK conversion themselves. We need them on thin matt card.

item.title: Join
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
Join Portsmouth Cycle Forum

Membership of Portsmouth Cycle Forum costs 5.00 per year. Your subscriptions help us to keep campaigning for a better deal for cyclists in the city. In April 2015 our annual subscription, which has been held at 5 for 5 years, will increase to 10 in order to meet our running costs. However, to beat the increase we're offering members the chance to renew their subscription for the current rate of 5 before March. If you are not currently a subscriber you can take advantage of this offer too by subscribing now as a member for 2014 and then renewing early for 2015. This way you will get 2 years membership for 10. If you'd like to join Portsmouth Cycle Forum you can do so ina number of ways.

Online

Optional Donation

You can join Portsmouth Cycle Forum Online and pay by paypal. We add an extra 40 pence to the membership charge to cover paypal's transaction fee. Just click on the button on the right to join right now. If you wish you can add a donation in the box - any contributions will be gratefully received. If you'd like to take beat the increased subscription fee for 2015by adding 2015 membership simply add a 5 donation to your application. We will do the rest. Clicking on the button will take you to the paypal site where you will be able to pay either by logging in to your paypal account or via a credit/debit card without using a paypal account.

By Email

Email membership@pompeybug.org.uk stating that you'd like to join the forum and we'll get back to you with instructions.

By Post

Write to us at: Portsmouth Cycle Forum 27 Thurbern Rd Portsmouth PO2 0PH

item.title: Community
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
Stacey Centre, Walsall Road, PO3 6DN

The Community Cycle Centre is open to the public every Saturday morning from 10am and we need your unwanted bike to pass on to the community.

We are always looking for bikes we can bring back to life and give back to the community.Either bring the bike along when we are open or contact us. We will bring them back to life and pass them on. Visit us at the Stacey Centre to Maintain your bike: Pop along and we will help you to keep your bike in good working order. How does it work? We are volunteers, mainly from the Portsmouth Cycle Forum we are entirely supported by donations.Typical donations are from 40 for an adult bike, 20 for a teenagers bike,10 for a child's bike. Repairs and maintenance will depend on how much work is required. Our Opening Times Open most Saturdays from 10am - 2pm. Contact us: 07434 560 099 either text or leave a voice message and we will get back to you. Like us on Facebook/communitycyclecentre and follow us on Twitter @communitycycle email us at community@pompeybug.org.uk Download or print a flyer.

[mappress mapid="6"]

Where are we? The Stacey Community Centre Walsall Road Copnor Portsmouth PO3 6DN www.staceycentre.org.uk

item.title: Newsletters
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
If you would like to contribute news, views or events to the newsletter, please contact us and we will be delighted to consider your contribution. Stories need to be around 100 words and preferably include a picture of some sort. More in-depth articles can be hosted on the website with a short summary in the newsletter.

item.title: Ben Norman Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: Many thanks for your letter regarding the Cycling Manifesto for Portsmouth. I am writing to you on behalf of the 14 candidates standing under the banner of the Trade Unionist and Socialist Coalition. Half of our candidates herald from the RMT union, so investment in a sustainable public transportation system, of which cycling should be a central component, is important to us. TUSC is committed to the idea of the democratic public ownership of the railways and for privatized bus services to be taken back under the democratic control of the council. Cycling should be the third major component of such a transport policy, with public investment in cycle routes, safety measures and other schemes to make cycling affordable, safe and enjoyable for all. It is my view that making Portsmouth a cycling city, akin to Copenhagen, Berlin or Amsterdam, would not only create jobs, but would make our city healthier, safer and more environmentally sustainable. It is with those aspirations in mind that we send this message in support of your manifesto. It is more than just working class nostalgia that stirs the memory of the thousands of workers cycling home from the dockyard each day in the 1950s and before. An enthusiasm for cycling is perhaps another example the modern workers movement should heed from our forebears. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Paul Smith Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: It appears from reading your Manifesto that you have put a great deal of hard work and thought into coming up with a set of measures that will help cyclists, motorists and residents alike. I myself am a keen cyclist (non driver) and know first hand about some of the dangers that cyclists face on a daily basis. As a candidate for the Charles Dickens ward in Portsmouth, I can empathize with you fully in respect of the dangers of there being inappropriate cycling provision. In regards to your suggestions I would fully endorse what you are putting forward and would like to put forward a suggestion myself of designated cycling days, with promotion of safety and cycle awareness. focusing on the green benefits, health benefits and economical benefits to the individual and the wider community of cycling in Portsmouth. Put forward as a way to tackle the challenges of living in such an overcrowded city. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Kirstine Impey Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: I have read through the manifesto and I would love to add my support to your cause. Having lived in Denmark for many years I have been use to a very cycling freindly country, one that I beleive we in the UK could learn a lot from. We should encourage people of all ages to use the bike as a mode of transport, teaching children from a very early age about road safety and generally supporting cyclist as much as possible. With regards to the safe routes around Cosham, I will be sending a street letter out to people in Highbury next week regarding the the Portsbridge round about, asking them for their ideas. Please feel free to use the following for you members and supporters to help identify solutions and options. The Portsbridge Roundabout under the A27 is going to be changed in the future. This is to allow for the building of the new office building between the Porsche garage and 1000 Lakeside This roundabout will get traffic lights on it to allow cars to get onto the roundabout from all directions. Several local residents have contacted me about changing the traffic layout to make it easier for poeple to get out of the Highbury Estate. If you have ideas on how traffi flows could be improved please let me know by e-mailing me at kirstineimpey@portsmouthlibdems.org.uk or dropping me a line at my home address, 19 Fairfield Square, Cosham, PO6 3JS. All the responses that I receive, will be put to Cllr. Gerald Vernon-Jackson and Cllr. Jason Fazackarley, to ensure that they are given to the officers in Transport and Environment to be taken into account when plans are being made for the new lay out. Any constructive support will be greatly appreciated. If all goes well at the elections on the 22nd I will be looking forward to working with you, if not I will still support your endevours as a Lib Dem campaigner and future candidate. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Ian McCulloch Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: I endorse every word of the cycling manifesto. As a member of the CTC I fully support the Space For Cycling campaign. The current cycling strategy in Portsmouth feels like a grudging response to being told to do something from above. The cycling map has glaring errors, trying to find a route from where I live in North End to Fratton station made me realise there are lines on the map which are one-way in different directions at different points, either there's an assumption that we will ride the wrong way down one-way streets, or they just didn't look that carefully. You call for better signage, and I would echo that. There are pavements that are marked on the cycling map as dual use, but there are no actual signs on some of those pavements. I'm very reluctant to use a shared use path that's not adequately marked for pedestrians. I used to live in Lancaster, one of the cycling demonstration towns. We brought in cycling contraflows very successfully, making the town much easier to cross by bike without hindering car traffic, I think there's a lot of scope for that in Portsmouth. This is an island with limited space, more bikes means less cars, that's a message we really need to get across. I'm old enough to remember the dockyard turning out in the '70s, hordes of bicycles pouring out of the Unicorn gate on the stroke of five o'clock. Back then the bicycle was standard working class transportation, now the media paints us as weirdos, taking up space that belongs to drivers. We have to challenge that view. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Ben Dowling Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: Being a cyclist myself, albeit a part time one, I'm happy to support the Cycle Forum's Manifesto. I agree that Portsmouth has the potential to be an ideal place for all people to enjoy cycling for both work and leisure and I acknowledge the various barriers to cycling currently. There is nothing in the Manifesto which I would be directly against. It is important for us to create an environment which is friendly to all road users. Having spent doing the short commute from the south of Portsmouth to Havant, I know only too well the necessity of having secure cycle parking at train stations. Whether elected or not, I am happy to take part in any discussions or planning in relation to this as I really do believe in the cause. In regards to the two points raised about Milton, I agree that dedicated cycle paths are indeed needed to and around the proposed Tesco development on Fratton Way. As for the road leading through St James' Hospital becoming a public right of way, I believe the Milton Neighbourhood Forum has looked into this before and it was dropped as there was no sign of the hospital preventing people from using it. With much of the site now due to be sold off and developed I would certainly want this to continue being a route open to the public. If this requires it becoming a public right of way, I would certainly support this. As a governor at Miltoncross School, a concern which has become clear to me is that the eastern side of Milton Road between Velder Avenue and the school needs to be made into a dual usage path. This would involve changing the types of bus stops there as well as new signage. I have previously asked that this be looked at by the council and I believe it has now been costed. I intend to push for this to happen as it will make a busy route to school much safer and I would much rather see lots of kids cycling to school rather than lots of parents driving into the school carpark everyday. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Andreas Bubel Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: I broadly support the aims in your Manifesto for better cycling facilities in Portsmouth and more specifically the concerns in Drayton and Farlington. Cycling is green and is a good thing if more people cycle, for health, for the environment and for the safety of pedestrians. It heightens awareness of surroundings and other people and is a reliable and effective form of transport. There is evidence I believe from many cities that bicycle provision is good for business as a cyclist is likely to visit a series of small shops but a car driver is more likely to go to supermarket, park and shop there. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Eloise Shavelar Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: As a Green Party member I support more sustainable travel in the city, I therefore back PCF's Cycling Manifesto for Portsmouth. As a driver and cyclist its is beneficial in both modes of transport to strengthen the cycling facilities in the city. As an island we must provide the infrastructure that supports those who can and want to cycle, walk and take buses to their destinations and with three central train stations and a scenic location more can be done to prevent over reliance on cars and improve the cycle network, which as you mention has great potential. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Simon Dodd Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
As a keen cyclist living in the city, I fully support all elements of the Cycling Manifesto. I think there are some excellent ideas that would indeed make cycling in our city easier and safer. Given that Portsmouth is a very densely populated city covering a relatively small geographical area, promoting cycling in the city can bring a number of benefits for us all, including health benefits (both through increased fitness as a result of cycling and through cleaner air if cycling is replacing driving), less congested roads and environmental benefits. Going through the manifesto, I support all the different elements - in addition, I'd like to make the following comments:
  • creation of a strategic green cycle network - as well as corridors into the city centre, should there be similar corridors to other key parts of the city for business, shopping or leisure, eg North End?
  • creation of liveable neighbourhoods - it's great to see the council including cycle storage facilities in new council houses - encouraging private developers to do this too would be a very good step forward
  • cycle & ride - following the introduction of this at the new park and ride facility, if successful it would be great to see this rolled out further, including hubs at key public transport interchanges
  • promoting new activities - all the ideas mentioned are good - in addition, I'd like to see whether an event similar to Sky Ride can be hosted in Portsmouth.
Looking at the concerns raised about Hilsea ward, I fully appreciate these and if elected I will do my utmost to push for solutions. It's incredibly important that we can develop safe infrastructure to encourage cycling in our city. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Hannah Hockaday Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: I strongly support such campaigns. I'll tell you why though rather than just being on the band wagon at election time... I've been leading the 'Safer Roads' campaign across Cosham, and it was covered in the Portsmouth News earlier this year. Firstly, with a petition for a crossing to be created at Highbury buildings and also with regards to the new so called 'improved' road layouts... which as you pointed out, have no provision for cyclists and have already proven dangerous in the form of a very serious accident recently. I cycle on a regular basis, usually with my daughter in a safety seat on the back of my bike. We tend to cycle on weekends, but due to the lack of cycle provision, cycle not on the roads around town, but at country parks where my daughters safety is better guaranteed. I live in Highbury Grove, near Highbury College and i've witnessed near misses on several occasions. During my campaign sessions residents have also been voicing their concerns about the road layouts and, a need for both safer roads as well as pedestrian and cycle provision. If i'm elected, i'll be in a better position to really make a better change for the area in terms of stepping up my campaign. I've often thought that Portsmouth City Council's strategy for cycle lane provision is half hearted at best. It seems that there is not a natural flow or continuation of cycle lanes like you'd expect, and in fact I think it makes it quite dangerous, especially on routes in and out of the city / island generally and for commuters travelling to work by bike. Anyway, this is probably a bit more than you wanted, but I think it's a much bigger issue than what a few sentences can address. It's quite alarming I'm happy to add my voice to your campaign and think that my natural feelings about the issues raised are very much inline with those of yours and your members. Back to Manifesto Responses

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: […] 5 supported our manifesto for cycling, 1 partially did and 8 did not respond. Bright spots are Hannah Hockaday(Con) in Cosham and Lee Hunt(Lib Dem) in Central Southsea who both gave us longand thoughtful […]
