item.title: Portsmouth Cycle Forum Newsletter No 1
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded: Image source is http://www.pompeybug.org.uk/img/Sample_Images/me_smallImg2.jpg

item.title: Tony Chafer Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: I am delighted to write in support of the Forum's proposals. Indeed I was for over 10 years the University's representative on the Forum and have cycled to work from my home in Southsea every day for 30 years. Investment in cycle routes so as to expand the network of safe cycle routes should be a top priority for the local council. The current low level of cycling in a city that is compact and flat - and therefore lends itself especially well to cycling - reflects years of under-investment in this form of travel, despite some undoubted improvements since the Forum was set up. But a huge amount remains to be done and I therefore wholeheartedly support the Forum's manifesto. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Alan Webb Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
Alan Webb:
  • Agrees with all points for creation of a strategic green cycle network
  • Believes that a greater use of contra flow systems may be dangerous, and that people may be confused about when they are allowed to cycle in guildhall / town centres. He agrees that safer routes to schools should exist.
  • Agrees with all other points in the manifesto.
Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Stephen Hastings Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: As a keen cyclist myself I absolutely agree with your points made regarding Portsmouth and the fact that you take your life in your hands on two wheels and in the modern world there should be provision for the mode of transport that pollutes the least. We are a university city and as such should pride ourselves on facilities for cyclists. Rest assured I will push for as much as possible to assist cyclists in Portsmouth and in particular for Baffins and I take on board all of your points well made regarding Baffins. Portsmouth is a very compact city with the University right in the heart and not out on a limb therefore is ideally suited to the cyclist. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Sue Greenfield Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: As a cycle owner, I agree that our city is ideally suited to cycling. In recent years though, I have become increasing wary of getting on my cycle and out on to our citys roads due increasing traffic and crowded streets. I also appreciate your concern about an inadequate cycle infrastructure in Hilsea. Over the last 18 months a number of residents have shared their concerns with me regarding road safety and I have followed these up with the City Council. I certainly support the aims and objectives of Portsmouth Cycle Forums campaign for better cycling facilities within the city. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Lee Hunt Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: If I am elected then I will be pleased to look at your proposals; however you will know there is currently no budget provision for a Goldsmith cycle lane on the north side 'similar to the seafront' at the moment, but I want cycle lanes that mean something much more. On such a lane I note your suggestions and can cause these to be investigated by professional officers and will email officers asking for enforcement as you describe. Two parking schemes (MC,MB), both covering the Priory School area have reduced on-street parking hugely - in some places easily by half and sometimes even more, so this makes crossing streets for pedestrians safer and means cyclists can see along the street better. I think for all of us the Dutch City of Groningen model for cycling (http://road.cc/content/news/96499-video-groningen-worlds-cycling-city-streetfilms) is something any large town and city can aspire to and I think we can see ele ments of this evolving here in Portsmouth; however the topography is rather different between the two cities - one has narrow Victorian streets and the other - although an ancient city, is not land-locked so has a lot of wider streets and more modern integrated areas after a major WW2 city battle and bombing with bridges blown up and the town centre devastated. With 57% of journeys undertaken by cycle the population think very differently, but the approach must help health and well-being too. There needs to be a huge 'sea-change' in UK 'PhySci' on this, but I believe it IS happening with British Cycling seeing tens of thousands of more members nationwide and huge interest around cycling. The trick is to get more politicians understanding this. There is no quick fix, but there is a 'direction of travel' evidenced as follows. I encouraged the new bicycle hire and accessories shop at Castle Field 'Dirt2Road' on the new national strategic Shipwright's Way: http://www3.hants.gov.uk/hats/findyourhat/eastcentralhathome/easthampshirehat/shipwrightsway.htm .... cycle route by talking with them and inviting them to bid for the premises - they also sell accessories etc; we are hiring bicycles from Tipner Park & Ride and Portsmouth Harbour Station http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/news/local/cycle-hire-scheme-given-go-ahead-to-tackle-congestion-1-3932150 - BUT we have still a long way to go ! Creation of a Strategic Green Cycle Network My hopes are reflected in the above paragraphs, which will accord with your members. As a member of the City Cabinet I can influence strategic and political thinking. Improved Safety Measures for cyclists in Portsmouth & Southsea Contraflow: Within my ward Central Southsea we already have contra-flow at Jubilee and Bath Roads one-way and I have been asked already to look at St. Augustine Road. Where it can happen safely, then I will support contra-flow. Precinct cycling: Allowing cycling in precincts 'outside of business hours' is something worthy of investigation. Expanding safe school bike routes: Expansion must go on. Creation of liveable neighbourhoods Making Portsmouth the UKs first 20mph city (except arterial roads) has helped improve motorists behaviour, which is beneficial for cycling. I gave my full support to Cllr Alex Bentley to help him do this. My approach in Central Southsea ward: In the city local ward I represent by working with residents to prevent and detect speeders, which are a danger to everyone including cyclists, I have been bringing in 'Speed Watch' and even getting 'snail' and 'tortoise' large posters on household bins - this all adds to the subliminal thinking as parents go by on foot and children ask about them, as well as motorists seeing them. Shutting down north/south city rat-runs like Frensham Road, St. Augustine Road, Fernhurst Road and Haslemere Road slows and introducing one-way systems at St. Augustine, Harold, Graham, Trevor, Bath, Henley and Jubilee Roads together with the circulatory system in Liss, Heyshott, Frensham and Empshott Roads sees local residents mainly using the highway, rather than passing-through motorists and calms traffic thereby enabling safer routes for cycling and hands residents back their own streets. Whereas 15 years ago Central Southsea Ward was the 'crossroads' of the city south with traffic whizzing through, that traffic now uses arterial routes - is slower, and the neighbourhoods are more 'liveable' and safer for all road users including cyclists. We see the above model increasingly citywide as in Fratton. There are some places like the Highbury Estate in Cosham where this approach is not applicable as the streets are ONE MILE long and need enforcement to deter speeding motorists; these streets lend themselves to cycling - so cyclists need to feel safe. Cycling Charter: I would be very interested to see your proposals for this Integration of bikes with public transport This is happening more and more (as above) and you will have seen the new plans for The Hard including bicycle parking. Throughout the city we have been installing more and more bicycle racks within view of CCTV. There have been several successes levering-in millions to promote sustainable transport. Encourage cycling throughout Portsmouth This is work in progress. The new 'Portsmouth Wiggle Triathlon' a partnership I procured with PCC/Triathlon England/Portsmouth Triathlon Club and working with British Cycling is helping to promote bicycling. A new Triathlon sports development post has been created and works closely with local sports clubs. A new sports strategy in partnership with the University of Portsmouth, NGBs, local sports clubs, Sport England and many other partners will further help progress bicycling. The City Council has less and less money, but must do more and more. So far we have been successful in 'delivering more for less' by creating partnerships working with local groups and volunteers and businesses. The council can help lead, enable, support and carry out some of the more local things 'Portsmouth Cycle Forum' promote by making small adjustments (local practical matters) and do better citywide with better strategic thinking. Money to do these things will only reduce for the foreseeable future, but we have been succesfull in bidding for transport monies so in the same way theatres, the Guildhall, community venues and sports are increasingly configured, I would like to see a 'Portsmouth Cycling Trust' created to bid for monies to bid for funding from the lottery and many different funders to empower bicycling and people to do some of the local initiatives the forum want to see throughout Portsmouth. This approach could be very advantageous: everyone will need to agree and it will need to be lead from the grassroots. https://www.transportxtra.com/magazines/parking_review/news/?id=37893 http://www.myjourneyportsmouth.com/portsmouth-gears-its-first-ever-community-cycle-hub http://www.myjourneyportsmouth.com/wayfinding Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Stuart Crow Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: Thanks for writing to me about the PCF manifesto, which I fully support. Id like to make some observations on how PCC can in future further cycling in the city, and also some on the current state of affairs in transport generally, which is deeply unsatisfactory. Creation of a Strategic Green Cycle Network This is something which PCC currently does not possess. Even within one journey along a given designated cycle route, it is likely that a user will encounter a number of different physical forms of path, changes of sharing and adjacency with other users, and disruptions to the flow of the route. A good example of this, on the borders of Milton Ward, is the Eastern Rd route, which is partly dedicated trackway, partly shared pavement, and partly segregated road space. Anything to encourage other forms of transport than cars along the eastern way in and out of Portsmouth should be encouraged and promoted. However, having cycled myself to work along that route to get to Farlington, I did not consider that route as it stands to be very helpful. It was safer than the road, but that was about it. The current format of junction at Velder Avenue/Milton Rd is a positive barrier to cycling, and signage along the route, explaining where to go next at either end of it is non-existent. As well as some general expenditure on the cycle network, Portsmouth has in the past accessed grant funding from central government to facilitate sustainable transport in general, and will be able to do so in future where funding is available some should be used to bring the existing network up to scratch as well as to support any new projects. There is a broader issue in that Portsmouth lacks connectivity between key cycling routes beyond the existing road network. There is a good route between the city centre and Fratton, but this is not promoted at the city centre end, and at the other end it ends in the unsatisfactory shared pavement environment around Fratton Bridge and Bradford Jn. The stretch of pavement alongside Victoria Rd North is a hazard to cyclists and pedestrians. Routes need better signage, and the shared pavement parts would benefit from proper demarcation. Beyond that, any new road schemes should be designed properly to accommodate cyclists, motor traffic, and pedestrians properly. There must be no repeat of the fiasco with the planned Tesco next to Fratton Park. The road layout there was already very poor, adding a fourth roundabout in a 300-yard stretch of road is nonsense (but I fear there is little that can be done in planning terms to stop it). Improved safety measures for cyclists Cycling still happens to a great extent through pedestrianised areas like Commercial Rd and Palmerston Rd anyway at all times of the day I dont know if there would be an appetite for introducing marked lanes to mark out cycle-paths but certainly in evenings when Commercial Rd is quieter it would make sense to permit cycling. The southern end of Palmerston Rd (the newly- and stupidly-pedestrianised bit) tends to be busier here the argument is much more for just reopening the entire road! The northern half, the older precinct, should be cycleable in the evening. Measures like the 20mph limit in unclassified roads are an aid to cycling, though I know there are some concerns that in particular roads the limit is ignored. Creation of liveable neighbourhoods This is something close to my heart, having grown up in Milton one of the most pleasant parts of the city, with a real community feeling. The layout of the rest of the city as it was redeveloped after the Second World War leaves a lot to be desired in terms of access for all forms of transport. We lost the grid pattern of terraced streets in much of Portsmouth and replaced it with a variety of alignments which are confusing to navigate. Planning policy and the City Plan already give a framework which allow the Council to ensure adequate access. However, city policies as they stand are unrealistic in their assessment of public transport provision and of the need to ensure adequate car parking in developments. That last bit might seem counter-intuitive from a cyclists point of view, but roads crammed with tightly-parked cars are hazardous, and devoting too much space to the housing element and not enough to amenities like parking has negative environmental impact over time. The City needs an all-round approach which encourages public transport and cycling and makes sure that where motor transport is used, it coexists safely and peaceably with the environment. The principles of the Making Space for Cycling document should inform future City planning. Integration of bikes with public transport This is generally poor. The PCC initiative of some years ago to introduce interactive bus stops with real-time information was completely the right thing to do, but the procurement and implementation were totally bungled and wasted large amounts of money. Our competitor cities already have systems in place (and did have before we tried it ourselves there were successful models to copy) and we look very backward in not having one now. Ive recently worked in Brighton, taking the train down there and using buses for onward journeys and the whole operation of public transport there seemed light-years ahead of Pompey. PCC has no power to compel bus operators to run a given service (unless PCC pays for it itself) but it should have influence. The changes FirstBus made to their routes and timetables at the end of 2012 were very badly-thought out, and yet PCC had nothing to say on the subject until there was a public outcry. That situation must not recur, and PCC should encourage First (or Stagecoach) to provide services that meet public demand. The eastern half of Portsea Island is now very poorly served by buses as a result of these changes. Improved signage of all forms of public transport will help (the new design of bus stop signage is a positive) and provision to secure bikes to permit onward journeys at key interchanges are things PCC can do itself to provide better integration. Bike integration with trains is good at Fratton in terms of parking, inadequate at Portsmouth & Southsea, and poor at the Harbour (where the same problem afflicts ferry users who dont travel with their bike). Improved safe parking provision is something PCC should be working with Network Rail and SWT on. The train service itself is often lousy, something I have frequently complained about on Twitter and my blog. We should be encouraging rail and bike as a means of commuting, and in future I hope we will have a park and rail strategy which will incorporate cycling as the third stage of commuting and tourism in Portsmouth. There may be scope for adding a cycling element to the park and ride operation at Tipner. The P&R system as it currently operates is a bodge the bus should run to Southsea as well, and to Fratton Park on matchdays. I note the overall long-term inadequacy of the Tipner car park, at 600 spaces, in terms of getting significant numbers of cars off the roads. Many comparable cities have P&R capacities well into the thousands, and we should aspire to that here. Encourage cycling throughout Portsmouth I think Ive already touched on a number of things that will encourage cycling by enabling it. The City Council already supports initiatives like the Cycle Hub in Winston Churchill Ave and I would be interested to hear feedback from your members on whether or not they feel it is doing the right sorts of things. Cycling as a leisure activity seems to be gaining in popularity and the number of events based on it is increasing. The difficulties the Strong Island collective have faced with insurance are a problem, and I am not sure how much PCC can do to get around that. As a flat, compact city Portsmouth should be a cyclists paradise. I do feel that we have to stop going backwards before we can go forwards and that means making the roads in general safer, making them flow better for all modes of transport, and to consult all user groups properly in the design of new developments. I am forever hearing from user and community groups that the City Council doesnt consult effectively, and it is a key part of my own manifesto that that has to change. Cycling has to form part of a proper strategy for all forms of transport, which at present seems to be lacking given the kinds of schemes under construction and planning around Portsmouth. Some of that we are stuck with, frankly, given the current financial position of local government. But there will be funds available through the Community Infrastructure Levy as developments happen that can be used to support sustainable transport. I note the present intention of the PCC administration to use CIL money to subsidize private business directly, and I strongly deprecate the idea. Public money intended to support infrastructure should not be diverted to other ends. Finally, in terms of the situation in Milton, of course I support the incorporation of a route through a redeveloped St James as a right of way, and the retention of the present pleasant environment in the area. The transport issue is going to be a key one as the site (and Langstone Campus) are redeveloped. I agree with your views on the Tesco planned for Fratton Park, and I gather it will now come before the Planning Committee in June. I expect I will make a deputation reiterating the inadequacy of the road layout. Id add one other issue to your list for Milton, which is that the Locksway Rd roundabout is still a danger, even worse now with the pinching of the road on the northbound side coming on to the roundabout. Ive nearly been knocked off a few times there, and it still needs more work. PCC wasted a huge amount of money on this through not thinking or listening properly! If I am elected, I will do everything in my power to ensure that people are listened to, and that the expert opinion of those with specialist knowledge informs the policy-making process. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Kevan Chippindall-Higgin Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: I read your cycling manifesto with interest and I agree with much of what you say. There are a couple of points that I would like to throw into the mix for consideration. Cycling in the precincts outside business hours seems reasonable until one examines those hours. In the new pedestrianised area of Palmerston Road and Guildlhall Walk/Square, business hours run through to around 3 in the morning. Given the cycles are silent, pedestrians partially deaf from clubs and almost certainly drunk, some of them extremely so, I am not sure that this is a happy combination in an area where a vehicle can reasonably be expected to be absent. I like the idea of the cycle contra flows that have been put in in a couple of the new(ish) one way systems. However, I would be very interested in your views of the safety of such arrangements. Vehicle drivers may reasonably expect all traffic to be going one way and finding a bike coming the 'wrong' way might cause problems. My thoughts are that cycle lanes should be properly painted onto the road surface to avoid confusion and the risk of missing or not understanding the signs. However, you are far better placed to report back on contra flow issues with cyclists and I would be interested to learn more. Painting a solid white line in Goldsmith Avenue would make no difference to parking. Enforcement would. I would be totally opposed to contra flow here because of the various junctions and entrances which cause traffic to legitimately squeeze to the left to pass right turning vehicles. Subject to the correct mirror checks, using the cycle lane is a sensible use of space. A contra flow along this road would be very dangerous indeed. As it is, there is no shortage of cyclists who treat the cycle lane as a free for all in terms of direction and I have had a couple of close shaves. Putting in a physical barrier similar to the sea front would make a busy, arterial route unacceptably narrow. I would like to see a legal mechanism whereby if a separate cycle lane exists, it is illegal to ride on the road. I would also like to see brakeless BMX bikes banned from any public space, including cycle lanes, and strict enforcement of mechanical safety, including lights, and illegal riding. I absolutely agree with you that cycling needs to be made more popular but not by putting people at risk by poor design. Interestingly, in Holland, where the bike is hugely popular, 21.4% of fatalities are cyclists compared to 5.6% in the UK. We therefore need to explore ways of combining legislation and enforcement with education to maximum benefit. I am horrified that we do not have road safety, cycling and driving as part of the National Curriculum. Nobody ever died due to not knowing Latin, but the same cannot be said of the roads. I will sadly be unable to attend your meeting at the Union on Thursday due to a prior engagement but if elected, will certainly wish to meet with your group to see what I can do to help to further cycling within the city. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Jonathan Kemp Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: I am a Trustee of the League of Friends of St Marys, and do use my bike to attend meetings when I am able, so improving access to the site would be most welcome some staff do use bikes themselves, and there is limited provision of bike racks outside the main entrance, but not enough, as a number of bikes are then padlocked to the barriers at the drop-off zone. I would be looking to have better access to the site, and also improved storage, especially as the parking area is extremely limited, and staff and patients should be encouraged to use alternative means of transport where possible. I am very encouraged by the popularity of the bike racks in Commercial Road often they are full but this would then indicate that there should be more available, so I would be looking to work with the Council officers to establish additional provision. Similarly for the main shopping area in North End, where the London Road has no cycle racks except adjacent to the Co-Op supermarket; again, people lock their bikes to crash / pedestrian barriers or lamp-posts. Personally, I would be in favour of allowing cycling through the Commercial Road pedestrian area outside peak times also Cosham High Street (at the top); again I would like to see additional provision for storage. Finally, a number of council staff and councillors themselves, are permitted to park for free beneath the Civic Offices I would be looking for this provision to be removed, and the recipients encouraged to use bicycles instead, thereby reducing costs to the City budget and providing additional parking facilities for essential council vehicles instead. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Frank Jonas Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
Notes taken during telephone conversation:
  • Supports manifesto (with exception of cycling in precincts).
  • Daughter lives in The Netherlands and he is keen to replicate here what they have there.
  • We need to encourage cycling from an early age. Make it the norm again. Work with schools.
  • He proposed a hierarchy of provision: 1) Pedestrians 2) cyclists 3) motor vehicles.
Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Jason Fazackarley Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: As the Current cabinet member for Traffic & Transportation the onus primarily rests with me to ensure that the promotion and implementation of cycling initiatives. I have welcome the variety of suggestions put forward by the Portsmouth Cycle Forum, during the course of the 4 years that I have held this portfolio, and for the attendance of its members at many of the T&T Decisions meetings. I fully recognise the value of promoting cycling, it is a recognised sustainable mode of transport and one that should be ideally suited for travelling around the City. That said I am aware of the concerns of cyclists for improved safety on roads and for the creation of more designated cycle lanes and this is something that I have been working with Highways Officers to progress. Areas in which Portsmouth City Council has been noticeably successful is in the securement of government grant funding and a number of multi-million pounds packages have been obtained. The Council has used this to increase a range of schemes under the Local Sustainable Transport Fund auspices. The new hub in Somerstown and the Park & Ride in Tipner are several examples of locations where cycle provision has been accommodated. The Traffic & Transportation portfolio is a tricky one to deal with, I face a vast array of representations from residents, businesses and organisations that have their individual ideas and desires. These often conflict with the wishes of someone else and I have to tread a fine balance between differing interests, often being accused of being anti-car, anti-cyclist, anti-pedestrian and / or anti-bus!! The truth is very much the opposite as I will seek to accommodate the ideas and suggestions that are put to me but it is impossible to please everyone! If I survive the forthcoming local elections then I will look forward to continued working with the Cycle Forum and doing what I can to forward cycling improvement within Portsmouth. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Suzy Horton Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: Thank you for your letter and Cycling Manifesto. As someone who spent most of her childhood cycling around Southsea, but has only in recent years returned to cycling, I appreciate the detail of the manifesto and am happy to support it. I am also a driver and a pedestrian, frequently pushing a wheelchair, and appreciate the pros and cons of all these modes of transport in our city and the challenge of allowing them to co-exist. I absolutely agree that Portsmouth has the potential for better cycling facilities for all and appreciate from talking to residents that many potential cyclists are dissuaded because of fears around safety and volume of traffic. Therefore I would not disagree with any of the suggestions cited in the manifesto, all of which would improve that experience. With specific reference to Eastney and Craneswater, I agree with the two areas of concern that you present. You are right when you say that the seafront cycle route is not universally popular but I have personally observed how busy it gets, especially with families during the kinder weather, and over the years people are getting used to its design. However, anyone who has used it would not fail to be inconvenienced but the arrangement at South Parade pier and I have already approached the cabinet member for Traffic and Transportation to reopen discussions to consider ways of having a less disjointed arrangement. Again, I agree that the respect for the cycle routes along Albert Road is limited. This is especially apparent on the stretch between Fawcett Road and Francis Avenue/ St.Ronans Road junction, compounded by the disregard of the double yellow lines outside the new Sainsburys on the south side of the road which forces traffic onto the opposite side of the road. In fact I requested a survey in that area in May last year and, not surprisingly, the results demonstrate that there is a problem and that several tickets were issued when enforcement officers were there. This is obviously symptomatic of a wider issue around convenience stores and perhaps the strategy of enforcement in such areas could be reviewed. The other issue in Eastney and Craneswater that is frequently presented to me when I talk to residents is the amount of cyclists on the prom. Mostly people do not like it. I see in your manifesto that you advocate cycling in the precincts after business hours and I fully endorse this as a positive step to a culture change towards more and more shared space. We will probably agree on the fact that changing views, perceptions and behaviour is a lengthy process but I am happy to aspire to a future of Portsmouth as a cycling city where there is a mutual respect of pedestrians, cyclists and drivers alike. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Ward Issues
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
As well as our manifesto for cycling, we asked each candidate to respond to two specific issues related to cycling in their ward.
Ward Ward Issues Description
Baffins Cycle access to St Marys via Guardian Gate Milton Road is a busy road with no cycle provision. Cycle access to St Marys hospital is difficult, if not unsafe for many cyclists. An alternative route is needed, connecting St Marys Road with Fratton Way and the rear of the hospital (as existed until recently). In the meantime creating a shared cycle/footpath would ensure cyclists safety.
Safe route to Portsmouth College on Tangier Road Tangier Road is a key route from central parts of the city to Portsmouth College. There is a short length of cycle lane close to the college but parking along a large part of the road forces cyclists into the path of following vehicles, creating potential conflict and danger. Marked cycle lanes each side would at least alert motorists to the presence of cyclists.
Central Southsea Parking on Goldsmith Ave cycle lanes Goldsmith Avenue is a key route on the citys cycle network with cycle lanes marked along a large part. Despite yellow lines, illegal parking on the cycle lanes is not enforced. An interim remedy would be to mark solid white lines to indicate do not cross as well as enforcement. A future solution would be to install a segregated two-way cycle track on the north side, similar to the seafront.
Safe routes to Priory School Priory School is within cycling distance for a large number of its students. However, it is surrounded by heavily-trafficked roads and residential streets full of parked cars. More effort should be made to create attractive, safe cycle routes. Urgent attention should be given to improving the crossings on Victoria Road North, where fast traffic is approaching or exiting the roundabout. In future a network of safe marked routes should be created from other parts of Central Southsea and Fratton.
Charles Dickens City Centre North cycle access Currently there is poor provision for cycling into the city centre from all areas, but particularly from the north and east. The lack of north-south and east-west routes leads to conflict in the pedestrianised areas. The plans for City Centre North show some improvements but involve multiple crossings over a relatively short distance. Additional improvements are needed to increase access from Landport/Buckland areas as well through routes. The major route along Marketway is too narrow and has blind bends. Any upgrade to the road network must allow sufficient width to bring the cycleway up to standard.
The Hard shared space Currently there are cycle lanes marked on The Hard but these are frequently blocked by vehicles, despite the double yellow lines. The Cycle Forum acknowledges that the redevelopment plans for The Hard show improvements for cycling but any measures such as marked cycle lanes need to be enforced. In addition allowance needs to be made for cycling into the transport interchange from both directions.
Copnor Copnor Road parking Copnor Road is a major artery in the city for all traffic. In the absence of alternative routes from the north to the southeast of the city, this road needs to be made more attractive to cyclists. Parking along a large part of the road forces cyclists into the path of following vehicles, creating potential conflict and danger. Marked cycle lanes each side would at least alert motorists to the presence of cyclists.
Safe routes to Mayfield School Mayfield School is within cycling distance for a large number of its students. However, it is surrounded by heavily-trafficked roads and residential streets full of parked cars. More effort should be made to create attractive, safe cycle routes. In future a network of safe marked routes should be created from other parts of Copnor and the north of the city.
Cosham Safe routes to Highbury College Highbury college is within cycling distance for a large number of its students. However, it is accessible only by crossing some busy roads. Existing infrastructure such as the A27 cycle/footbridge should be more clearly signposted, as well as the route from Cosham station. In future a network of safe marked routes should be created from other parts of Cosham and the north of the city.
Safe routes to QA Currently there are no marked cycle routes directly into QA Hospital. Southampton Road has poorly maintained cycle paths, shared with pedestrians, but no route is marked, even from Cosham centre. It may not be practical to expect visitors or staff to cycle from home but certainly a clearly defined route from the railway station is possible and desirable.
Drayton & Farlington Safe routes to Springfield School Springfield School is within cycling distance for a large number of its students. However, it is surrounded by busy roads and residential streets full of parked cars. More effort should be made to create attractive, safe cycle routes. In future a network of safe marked routes should be created from other parts of Drayton & Farlington.
Farlington Ave calming Traffic calming measures were applied at the top of Farlington Avenue to slow traffic down, but what should have made the road safer has endangered cyclists. Going downhill, cyclists have been given a cut-through to avoid the chicane, whereas going uphill, cyclists are forced into the chicane, in the path of following cars. There is adequate space on either side to allow a cut-through for cyclists, and we asked Portsmouth City Council to modify the scheme at the time it was proposed.
Eastney & Craneswater South Parade Pier safe cycle route While the seafront cycle route may not have been universally popular, even among cyclists, on a summer day it is busy with families and groups of older children. Now that there is a marked cycling/walking route across Southsea Common, it is vital that a safe route next to South Parade Pier is installed to complete the seafront cycle route.
Parking on Albert Road cycle lane Cycle lanes have been marked on Albert Road, albeit with long gaps. Despite yellow lines, illegal parking on the cycle lanes is not enforced, and is especially bad near to traffic lights. Such parking forces cyclists into the path of following vehicles, creating potential conflict and danger. Excessive parking and throughflow of traffic discourages shoppers from spending more time on Albert Road. An extension of the shared space by the Kings Theatre would make a more pedestrian and cycle-friendly environment.
Fratton Fratton Road traffic lights green wave The numerous traffic lights on Fratton Road/Kingston Road make for stop-start journeys for all road users, but they encourage drivers to speed up before the lights change, endangering pedestrians and cyclists. Setting lights to red until a vehicle approaches would avoid this danger, and giving cyclists 5-10 seconds start with their own signals also reduces potential conflict.
Safe routes to City Girls School City Girls School is within cycling distance for a large number of its students. However, it is surrounded by busy roads and residential streets full of parked cars. More effort should be made to create attractive, safe cycle routes. In future a network of safe marked routes should be created from other parts of the city.
Hilsea Shared access Peronne Road northbound Peronne Road leads to the shared cycle/footbridge over the A27 into Cosham and Highbury College and is an ideal quiet route for cyclists. However, the busy one-way system where Copnor Road and London Road meet is not cycle-friendly. Creating a wide shared cycle/footpath between Peronne Road and Norway Road would allow throughflow of cyclists between Cosham, Hilsea and Copnor.
Narrow shared path on Portsbridge The cycle paths around Portsbridge roundabout are a vital part of the Portsmouth cycle network, connecting the western side of Portsea Island with the rest of the city and beyond. At several points there are bottlenecks where two cyclists can barely pass safely, regardless of other users of the paths. Space is available around the roundabout to create a safe shared route for pedestrians and cyclists. PCC has previously proposed these improvements but no change has been made.
Milton Tesco Fratton Way cycle access When the Fratton Way retail park was built space was allocated for cycling, segregated from traffic and footpaths. The proposed Tesco store provides an opportunity to encourage a wide uptake in cycling into and around the development, thus reducing the probable traffic congestion around the store. However, proposed improvements during the consultation have become less clear with the outline planning application. To encourage cycling, dedicated cycle paths to and around the store are needed, including on Milton Lane and across Fratton Way.
St James Hospital right of way Walking and cycling is permitted through St James Hospital grounds, although it is not designated as a public right of way. This is an attractive route between Locksway Road and Moorings Way, and our concern is that redevelopment of the site will reduce or remove through access. We ask for support to apply for a public right of way through the grounds.
Nelson Twyford Avenue cycle lanes Cycle lanes marked on Stamshaw Road and Twyford Avenue are very narrow, passing very close to parked cars, with the danger from doors opening. There should be proper enforcement to prevent vehicles blocking cycle lanes. If residents parking schemes are to be extended in this area, consideration should be given to removing some of the parking spaces, or moving them away from conflict with cyclists.
Park+Ride cycle access Many millions have been spent on the Park and Ride at Tipner, and we hope this is a success in reducing congestion coming into the city centre. Folding bikes are available to hire to encourage visitors to see more of the city, but there are no clearly defined cycle routes from here. Routes to the City Centre, Cosham and the Mountbatten Centre should be created to encourage cycle use.
Paulsgrove Tipner-Port Solent link Plans for development at Port Solent and Tipner indicate a bus-only bridge to be built linking the two communities. Reference is made to allowing cycling, but the design should give segregated space for pedestrians and cyclists to avoid conflict.
Safe routes to QA Currently there are no marked cycle routes directly into QA Hospital. Southampton Road has poorly maintained cycle paths, shared with pedestrians, but no route is marked, even from Cosham or Paulsgrove. In future a network of safe marked routes should be created from other parts of the north of the city.
St Jude Safe route from city centre There are numerous marked cycle routes in Portsmouth, but surprisingly none of them link the two main shopping centres of Southsea and the City Centre. To encourage more visitors to the Southsea shops and seafront, a quiet route should be marked from Portsmouth and Southsea railway station.
Parking on Elm Grove cycle lanes Cycle lanes are marked on Elm Grove, albeit with long gaps. Despite yellow lines, illegal parking on the cycle lanes is not enforced, and is especially bad close to traffic lights. Such parking forces cyclists into the path of following vehicles, creating potential conflict and danger. Excessive parking and throughflow of traffic discourages shoppers from spending more time on Elm Grove. Improvements such as giving cyclists 5-10 seconds start with their own signals also reduces potential conflict at busy junctions.
St Thomas Safe routes to University The main University campus is within cycling distance for most of its students. A large number of students live close to the main east-west route along Winston Churchill Avenue, but this is poorly marked, with a number of busy junctions such as Victoria Road North and Cambridge Road. Other safe routes from Kings Road area would make cycling a more attractive means of travel. In future a network of safe marked routes should be created from other parts of the city to the University.
Safe route to seafront PCC has created a cycle route across Southsea Common to the Seafront and South Parade Pier, linking with the popular segregated cycle track east of the pier, but this is not complete. A safe cycling route linking the Seafront with Old Portsmouth and The Hard Interchange would encourage more residents and visitors to leave their cars at home, reducing congestion on busy days.
Back to Manifesto Responses

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: […] As well as our manifesto for cycling, we asked each candidate to respond to 2 specific issues related to cycling in their ward. Those issues are listed here. […]

item.title: Graham Heaney Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: I am happy to support the key points of your cycling manifesto for Portsmouth. This is even more important after the recent report from the Department of Transport about cyclists being at such high risk of being involved in accidents in the city. If elected in Cosham I will work with you to tackle the two issues you mention in your letter about safe routes to Highbury College and safe routes to QA hospital. We need to ensure that the council gets access to appropriate government funding that may be available and make safe cycling a real priority in the council in its transport and environment plans and budgets. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Rob Smith Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: I fully support the points raised in the manifesto and I believe that they would help fulfill key health, environment, transport and leisure outcomes in the city. As a non-driver I use my bike to get around the city and cycling is a big part of my familys weekend. I would like to see a much bolder and ambitious approach to cycling policy by the council. Portsmouth is perfectly suited to cycling and its density and congestion problems make improved cycling opportunities even more relevant and essential. If elected I look forward to working with you in my ward and pressing the case for improved cycling policy in the council chamber. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Paul Godier Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: I think your manifesto is great and I would be happy to support your campaign. However I must confess I know very little of how the traffic is controlled, and as yet not confirmed in a particular role where I could help. This would make it impossible to say what I would do. I can only be honest and open about how I feel about the situation and give my view as I see fit. I have read your manifesto and given all points my full attention as I see fit. My concerns. Useing the precincts out of hours. I feel that with food outlets, bars and public transport links there is potential for accidents. There are many situations I see. So I will be honest. Without debate I couldn't see this work. Integrations with public transport links. I like this idea. But again would need to hear more. I suppose if the council and the transport firm's could come up with a workable plan, then I see no problem. But. I would like to hear more about how we accommodate such schemes. I would also like to hear more about your proposals for a cycling charter and what it would entail. As for the rest. Very interested. Expecially in the safe bike routes to school and promoting cycling activities. I think our council should be fully behind or at least working close with your forum. I think our city is perfect for cycling so maybe we could look at other cities at how they manage this situation. Our current attempts at traffic flow and road maintenence seem very irratic and none perminant. In the future I would expect to see our council consult its electorate over major issues that concrrn them. UKIP will introduce referendums on major issues that do concern its electorate. So I hope I answered your questions and would be happy to discuss further in what ever role I will play. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.title: Peter Eddis Comments
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: As one of the few Councillors who cycles everywhere in the city I have always been very supportive of the Portsmouth cycle forum and in particular worked some years ago with Hilary Reid and still work closely with John Holland with whom I have had many discussions of cycling issues. I also had regular dealings with Jayne Rodgers. Specific issues have been getting more cycle stands in many areas of Southsea including the Precinct, D Day museum car park, Albert Rd traffic lights and many more in association with Jayne Rodgers. The much improved traffic lights at Grove Road south and Albert road were the result of a long campaign by me and my ward councillor colleagues. Unfortunately the detail was not discussed with me and so after installation John Holland, Jayne Rodgers and I met and produced a long defect list much of which has now been done. I am afraid the same can't yet be said for the Victoria Rd traffic lights where there have been some improvements but also some very serious hazards introduced for cyclists the latest of which is the recommended use of Victoria Grove by vehicles instead of Outram Rd This is a narrow two way road and was route for cyclists avoiding hazards at these lights particularly the serious pinch point introduced if coming south with an offset traffic island for pedestrians. The problem is not the traffic island per se but the fact it is a pinch point and introduces a serious cyclists hazard. There have been and will continue to be many more cyclists issues which I shall continue to work on with John and others but I will take some credit for helping Jane and the cycle forum getting the route of the long distance cycle and pedestrian path (shipwrights way) through Southsea and Old Portsmouth agreed. We still have the issue of the sea front to resolve. Working together we will win improvements in the end. I believe when the sea defences are improved in 2 years time we will achieve a much better solution for all including cyclists. I am very involved in insuring cyclists are fully catered for as part of the new sea defences. There is much to be done throughout the city but I have and will continue to focus my efforts on Southsea. I probably know most of the black spots but I always welcome anyone telling me their black spots particularly if they can suggest a practical solution. Sadly there are some where I can't see obvious solutions. But one I am continuing to lobby for and trust the cycle forum will continue to support me is making the cycle lanes at the traffic lights in Albert Rd and Elm Gr mandatory as both are usually blocked by vehicles sometimes unloading but often just stopped there. Back to Manifesto Responses

item.content:encoded: In respect of your manifesto I am supportive of cycling in the city, a leisure cyclist myself, and in Baffins Ward we have issues with access to St Mary's so would like to review some proposed routes also, Tangier road and access to Portsmouth College. item.title: Portsmouth second only to few London boroughs for pedestrian & cyclist casualties
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="alignright" width="332"] Total Cycle Casualties in Portsmouth[/caption] According to several sources (including the Department for Transport and Portsmouth City Council) in 2013 Portsmouth retained the unenviable record of being the worst English Local Authority for vulnerable road user casualties outside London. The vulnerable road user classification includes pedestrians and cyclists, so this issue affects adults, children and the elderly. Portsmouths Active Travel strategy depends on cycle use, and therefore the safety of cyclists, however, there is an upward casualty trend over the last six years. Over the same period, Portsmouths contribution to the UKs cycle casualties remained steady, providing around 5% of accident victims. The UK has seen annual increases in cyclist mileage over other modes of transport, however Portsmouth has not. This brings Portsmouths casualty rates into question. If cycling is not increasing in line with the rest of the country, why are cycling accidents keeping pace?

Why is cycle use not increasing?

In 2013 there were 1408 casualties among vulnerable road users in Portsmouth, of which 318 were killed or seriously injured (KSI), and 316 involved children under 16. PCC's own surveys in schools and workplaces, said:
'the main barriers to cycling are concerns about the volume and speed of traffic, personal safety, lack of continuous cycle lanes or safe cycle routes, ...'
and:
'there is an issue around volume of traffic and the behaviour of a proportion of drivers in the city, and this can often make people feel vulnerable and lacking in the confidence to ride on the roads.'
and:
'It is mainly women who say that lack of confidence on the roads is a major reason why they dont cycle/cycle more'.
Lynne Stagg Lord Mayor and former Cabinet Member for Traffic and Transportation, who said in 2010: I dont cycle any more. The roads arent safe. In Portsmouth, with the worst cycling casualty figures outside London and a widespread fear of cycling for safety reasons, fewer than 5% cycle to work - unchanged for a decade. In Copenhagen, which prioritises works to make cyclists safe, 36% commuted by bike, including children travelling to school.

Where do accidents happen?

DfT's figures show that cyclists are four times more likely to be casualties on Urban A roads than on Urban Other roads. This is due to the lethal effect of the higher speed on A roads, creating a toxic mix of two-way motor traffic, cyclists and pedestrians - including, of course, children and the elderly. Then add in parked cars, bus stops, multiple side roads, major junctions, rush hours and the dropping off and picking up of children at school - all on Portsmouths narrow and congested streets. Portsmouth's road accident figures show this is a recipe for mayhem and its the vulnerable road users who are paying the price - with terrible consequences for families, friends and colleagues - years after the initial accident.

What can be done?

Last year, when the 2011 figures came out, a PCC spokesperson said:
...we are the most densely-populated area outside central London. As cyclists are more likely to have accidents on busy urban streets, this might also have an impact on our figures.
Portsmouth Cycle Forum says this is no excuse. For safety, the Department for Transport (DfT) recommends applying a user hierarchy to the road design process with pedestrians at the top. Clearly, vulnerable road users need protection from the lethal speed and weight of cars, vans, buses and lorries, often passing them just a hairs breadth away. One distraction; an unexpected event, and a cyclist or pedestrian is put at risk - weve all seen it happen, day after day. When they are protected - as Copenhagen shows - many more people choose to walk and cycle and accident rates plummet. The bottom line is that sections of Portsmouths A road network are just too narrow to safely accommodate the volume and mix of todays traffic. A change must be made if we are to stop these casualties. In A Cycling Strategy for Portsmouth: Draft for Consultation, in 2009, PCC endorsed the DfT road user hierarchy approach, giving priority to pedestrians and cyclists. Isnt it about time this was put into practice on Portsmouths Urban A roads - to stop us having the worst casualty rate outside London for another year?

item.title: Subway Survey
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
Portsmouth City Council have been reviewing their inventory of pedestrian subways and underpasses with a view to closing some of them in order to save on maintenance charges. Since many underpasses are also used by cyclists (legally!), we decided to conduct a survey of our own.

The results are attached in the document below. Generally we found that most of the remaining underpasses are still of use to both pedestrians and cyclists although they are not always pleasant places. We'd like to see a programme of environmental and lighting improvements to make them more attractive and safer to use.

What do you think?

item.title: Cycling in One-Way Streets
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
Image source is http://www.pompeybug.org.uk/img/Road_Signs/me_No_motor_vehicles.jpg

Whenever there is a new proposal for a one-way street then local residents are, quite rightly, consulted.

However many of the roads proposed are quiet and frequented by cyclists who are not necessarily residents.

We have persuaded the City Council to widen their consultation process so that the views of all people using the road are collected.

In addition, we have asked that contra flow cycling is considered when new one-way schemes are proposed.

With the city-wide introduction of the 20 mph speed limit on minor roads this is now a very practical solution providing there is sufficient carriageway width.

Many of you will be familiar with Paradise Street where there is a contra flow cycle lane.

Stafford Street in Southsea has a workable arrangement where only bicycles are allowed to enter the road from Victoria Road South. The Cycle Forum has started to compile a list of one-way streets where we think that contra flow cycling is practical.

item.title: Albert Road traffic calming - What do you think?
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
The traffic calming scheme in Albert Road by the Kings Theatre is largely completed and we are seeking views of cyclists on whether you like it or not.

Kerbs have been dropped to blur the distinction between pavement and carriageway with the intention of giving the road a relaxed "continental" appeal.

Coloured and stainless-steel bollards stop vehicles encroaching into pedestrian areas. These have been enlarged to allow more space for tables and chairs outside shops, pubs and cafes.

Generally, space has been reclaimed for pedestrians from the motor car - not a bad thing (well

cyclists would say that, wouldn't they!).

The taxi rank has been moved back along Albert Road and some on-street car parking has been removed.

So, what do you think?

Some cyclists have expressed concern that the roadway is narrower than before and that they feel that they are being pushed into the the path of vehicles.

Others have noticed an increase in pavement cycling (or more correctly, cycling in the pedestrian areas).

It has been suggested that a marked cycle lane should be created on the pedestrian side of the bollards in the narrowest sections.

We would like to see the imposition of a 20mph speed limit in this part (and all parts) of albert Road.

Please tell us your views

Click on the

Link target is /enquiry/

Link text is Contact Us

Contact Us

link.

We'll collate the replies and let you know everyone's views.

item.title: One-way Streets
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
Image source is http://www.pompeybug.org.uk/img/Road_Signs/me_One_way_up_road_sign.jpg

Alex Bentley, PCC executive member for traffic and transport, was asked to approve recommendations on this subject at a decision meeting on 19 September.

The methodology proposed for evaluating the need for such schemes and the feasibility of implementing them took no account of cycling.

Link to the paper below.

John Holland and Paul Dawson made a deputation on behalf of the forum to draw attention to the need to evaluate the impact on cycling in this case and in the development of other highway schemes.

They suggested that there should be a presumption that all one way streets should be provided with cycle contra-flows.

Charles Stunell, head of traffic and street management agreed with this.

There is a target in the Portsmouth Cycling Strategy (see link below) to provide contra-flow cycle facilities on all non-classified residential one-way streets by 2015.

This would be a good time to draw to the council

item.title: Data Protection Act
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
Image source is http://www.pompeybug.org.uk/img/clipart/me_padlock.gif

Portsmouth Cycle Forum is a not for profit organisation.

It is thus exempt from registering under the Data Protection Act 1998 but is required to meet the other requirements of the Act.

Personal Data will be kept only for the purpose of allowing participants or potential future participants to be notified of forum activites and to communicate with each other.

This data will comprise no more than names, addresses, telephone numbers and e-mail addresses.

Data will not be disclosed to any other party unless there is a legal obligation to do so.

This document has three aims.

Firstly, it describes how the Government is responding to the recommendations made in the Eddington study to improve transport

item.title: Proposed changes to bus and cycle lanes at Hilsea
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
Portsmouth City Council proposes to make the following Order under Sections 1 to 4 of the Road Traffic Regulation Act 1984. The effect of the Order will be as follows:

A) PROVISION OF BUS, TAXI, AND CYCLE LANE

1. LONDON ROAD The west side, from a point 30m south of Portsbridge Roundabout northwards to Portsbridge Roundabout.

2. NORTHERN PARADE The north-west side, from a point 4m north-east of its northern junction with Hilsea Crescent to the existing bus, taxi, and cycle lane.

B) RE-ALIGNMENT OF BUS, TAXI, AND CYCLE LANE

1. LONDON ROAD The east side, around the new build-out on the north-west side of the northern end of Northern Parade.

2. NORTHERN PARADE The north-west side, around the new build-out at its junction with London road.

For full details of this Traffic Regulation Order (TRO 46) see the

Link target is http://www.portsmouth.gov.uk/living/609.html

item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded: Image source is http://www.pompeybug.org.uk/img/Photographs/me_Sheffield_stands_and_bikes_02.gif Do you cycle in Portsmouth? Do you ever resort to chaining your bike to railings, trees, streetlights etc. because there is no convenient cycle parking? We've been asked by the leader of the Council, Gerald Vernon-Jackson, to come up with a list of 30 sites for secure bicycle parking in the city. By "secure" we understand that Sheffield type stands are intended and these can be in groups or ones and twos or more - near shops, restaurants, community centres, schools, stations, houses ... So, please tell us where you'd like to see bicycle parking by clicking on the Link target is /enquiry/ Link text is Contact Us Contact Us link and we'll feed the information back to Portsmouth City Council.

item.title: Northern Quarter Cycle Routes
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
Image source is http://www.pompeybug.org.uk/img/Photographs/me_NQ_map_1.jpg

The Northern Quarter is the name given to the proposed retail development to the north of Portsmouth City Centre which includes the site of the former Tricorn Centre.

Portsmouth Cycle Forum consider the proposed changes to the road layout in the plan by developers Centros

do not provide sufficient access for cyclists.

Some simple, cost-effective changes could be made to give a serious boost to cycling in the city, improve the environment, reduce traffic congestion and help make this a fitter, healthier city.

The current scheme gives little incentive to anyone to get out of their cars and onto their bikes.

We have produced two documents which detail the shortcomings together with our proposals for improvements.

With Centros currently re-designing

the scheme,

there exists

an ideal opportunity to make changes for the better.

Our proposal documents may be found below.

item.title: Waitrose launches free bike trailers ...
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
Image source is http://www.pompeybug.org.uk/img/Photographs/me_Waitrose_cycle_trailer_loan_scheme_Chichester.jpg

The Web site Bikeradar reports that some 21 Waitrose stores across the country are introducing free bike trailers to help shoppers get their goods home by bicycle.

Equipped with large canvas shopping bags, the trailers will be loaned out for a day free of charge to any Waitrose customers who wish to use them.

The supermarket hopes the scheme will encourage its customers to cycle to its stores rather than travelling by car.

The nearest participating branches are in Gosport and Chichester (pictured).

We hope the scheme is successful and urge Waitrose to bring the facility to the Southsea store as soon as possible.

Links :

item.title: Vote for "The Route"
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
Image source is http://www.pompeybug.org.uk/img/Posters/me_theroute2.jpg

The Route is a vision by architect Carl Leroy-Smith of Deer Park Aplha for a series of routes crossing the city of Portsmouth that are designed with pedestrians, cyclists and buggy users in mind, where the car would be an occasional guest.

They are part of a vision for Portsmouth that is aimed at making it a liveable city.

The Route 001 starts at Castle Road in Southsea, passes through Guildhall Square, and continues for 5km (3 miles) north to Alexandra Park and the new fifty-metre swimming pool at the Mountbatten Centre.

It creates a series of vibrant places that connect the neighbourhoods of Somerstown, Landport, Buckland and Stamshaw. There are already lots of interesting things to see and do along the route - this project suggests others that could be added. It takes 1 hour to walk the entire route and 20 minutes to cycle leisurely.

Although this particular route has been focused on, it could be the first of many (see next slide). There are very few major changes required to realise the Route in its simplest form - the starting point for all the ideas shown here is a Route that already exists and simply needs to be defined.

You can register your support for the project by signing the on-line petition at

Link target is http://www.gopetition.com/petitions/the-route.html

item.title: Hampshire Summer of Cycling Launch
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
Image source is http://www.pompeybug.org.uk/img/Photographs/me_Summer_of_cycling_launch_01.jpg

Scores of cyclists rode to Gunwharf Quays to visit Portsmouth Cycle Forum's Giant cycling map on Bank Holiday Saturday.

Cyclists were of all ages and included fit pensioners and families with helmeted toddlers.

They plotted the worst danger spots around the city, shared their favourite routes and stories of adventure, and fitness gained.

The lean pensioners were evidence of the health benefits of pushing pedals. Members of the Forum heard of local cycle trips to the shops, to work and to places all over the world - well off the beaten track.

item.title: Lakeside Planning Application Approved
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_4" align="alignright" width="250" caption="1000 Lakeside"][/caption] The deferred planning application for a new business development at Lakeside, North Harbour wasapproved at the City Councils Planning Committee on9 December. Councillors on the planning committee expressed the view that it was not incumbent on the developers to provide anyfurther sustainable transport infrastructure. They did however, agree that cycle infrastructure at Portsbridge is fundamentally inadequate and that something must be done. The implication would seem to be then that PCC will take some action itself. Councillor Luke Stubbs (Conservative) spoke in favour of the proposals stressing the need for more jobs in the city. He made no mention of the need to reduce dependence on the car for travel to and from the site. He proposed that the application should be passed by the planning committee. Councillor Jacqui Hancock(Liberal Democrat) was silent throughout the proceedings with the exception of seconding Cllr Stubbs proposal. Councillor Jim Fleming (Liberal Democrat) sympathised with the objectors but felt that the developers had made efforts to accomodate the wishes of the city planners. Councillor Donna Jones (Conservative) shared Cllr Phillip's view. She said that it wasa case of risk vs reward - the risk of increasing Portsmouth's carbon footprint vs the rewards of people having jobs in order to be able to buy bicycles to enjoy cycling. She quoted a letter form a constituent who asked "if there were no more cars in Portsmouth, would the threat of flooding from the sea recede?"
Portsmouth Cycle Forum (PCF)committee member MikeDobsonmade an impassioned plea to the committee not to approve the scheme. Whilst PCF does not object to the development per-se, we have grave concerns that the transport plans make little provision for pedestrians and cyclists. This view was backed-up by CTC Right-to-Ride representative Jon Spencer. Whilst we are disappointed that the Lakeside development has been approved withinadequate sustainable transport provision, the developers, Highcross, have agreed to an open dialoge with us. We look forward to a useful and constructive relationship which will bring benefits to pedestrians and cyclists.

item.title: What one thing would make cycling in Portsmouth better?
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_443" align="alignright" width="150" caption="PCF at D-Day 65"][/caption] What one thing would make cycling in Portsmouth better? was the question asked of over 100 cyclists who visited Portsmouth Cycle Forums stands at the D-Day charity Bike Rides, and the British Heart Foundation Round the Harbours charity ride. (6/7 June 2009). Over 1400 cyclists from 8 months to 80 years old, on mountain bikes, racers, tourers, tandems and trailers spun their way round Portsmouths coastline in the two-day sunny celebration of cycling. Portsmouth Cycle Forums team displayed their giant cycling map. Visitors to the PCF stands discussed and plotted on the map the most dangerous places to ride a bike in Portsmouth. Over 100 riders joined the PCF e-mail network in support of PCFs aim to advocate more, safer cycling in Portsmouth.

item.title: Southsea Seafront Cycle Route draft plans revealed
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_440" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Southsea Seafront Contraflow"][/caption] Phase 1 Plans Revealed Portsmouth Cycle Forum was invited to look at the draft drawings of the first phase of the cycle route along Southsea seafront. This section extends from South Parade Pier to Henderson Road along Southsea Esplanade and Eastney Esplanade. Having seen these drawings and after clarification on some of the plans, we submitted our comments to councillors for consideration. Our concerns We are particularly concerned that cycle lanesare shown topass directly behind the echelon car parking for much of the way. In our view this isvery dangerous since drivers reversing from them simply cannot see cyclists approaching. We are also concerned that the route is designed for experienced cyclists only. Anyone new to cycling or returning to cycling will be reluctant to negotiate busy roads with parked cars.This is not a good proposal for children and other vulnerable cyclists.

item.title: Portsmouth Green Fair
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_437" align="alignleft" width="177" caption="Green Fair Poster"][/caption] Portsmouth Cycle Forum attended the Portsmouth Green Fair in the Guildhall Square on Saturday 5 September. We spoke to many people including counillors, prospective MPs and cyclists - one of whom was on his way from Birmingham to Bilbao - by bike of course! The day ended with a Q andA session on Southsea Seafront cycling with PCAN's Alan Burgess posing questions to Gerals Vernon-Jackson, Leader of Portsmouth City Centre. More information at thePortsmouth Climate Action Network web site.

item.title: Cycling group criticises Lakeside development plans
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_426" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Less than generous provision for cyclists at Portsbridge"][/caption] The delayed planning application for a new business development at Lakeside, North Harbour was deferred at the City Councils Planning Committee on 14 October. The developers, Highcross, boast that the flagship scheme will have excellent green credentials and claim that the it will encourage people to use sustainable travel (walking, cycling and buses). The Portsmouth Cycle Forum is one of many organisations objecting and has pointed out that the plans for the pedestrian and cycle routes to Lakeside are seriously inadequate. Government climate change carbon reduction targets mean that Portsmouth needs to encourage people to leave their cars at home and use sustainable transport options instead. But the few improvements planned for the shared pedestrian and cycle paths will not be enough to provide safe and attractive routes that will persuade people to travel sustainably. Highcross have assumed a steady growth in the numbers of people wanting to drive to Lakeside and they plan to widen the roads and the Portsbridge roundabout to take this growth in polluting motor traffic. However, Consultants Capita Symonds have made no allowance for the increase in cycling that the Council wants. The plans do nothing to remove a major bottleneck on the main pedestrian and cycle route from Portsea Island to Lakeside and the plans wont provide enough light controlled road crossings for cyclists and pedestrians to cross the Lakeside access roads in safety. Portsmouth Cycle Forum urges the developers to think again and make improvements to the pedestrian and cycle infrastructure. This must be a truly sustainable development and not just one that ticks boxes on a sheet of paper.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Cycling group criticises Lakeside development plans
Cycling group criticises Lakeside development plans

item.title: Seafront Cycle Route Gets Green Light
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_405" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Southsea Seafront Contraflow"][/caption] Portsmouth City Council approved the first phase of the Southsea Seafront cycle route at the Cabinet Meeting on 9 November. The route will be on the road between Eastney Swimming Pool and South Parade Pier, next to the promenade. The dangerous echelon (angled) parking bays will be replaced with spaces parallel to the road. Portsmouth Cycle Forum welcomes this decision and we look forward to the opening of the route in the spring of 2010. We spoke in support of the proposals at the meeting along with the CTC and the Portsmouth Disability Forum. Southsea Seafront Traders were concerned that the loss of 150 parking spaces would impact their businesses, however the figures presented showed that these spaces were full on very few occasions during the year. At the busiest times, overflow parking will be available on Southsea Common and councillors agreed to look at other sites to replace the spaces that will be lost. The permanent Park and Ride system will provide much needed relief to the parking problems in Portsmouth and Southsea when it comes on-stream. The route for Phase 2, from South Parade Pier to Clarence Pier, has yet to be decided. We will be working with Portsmouth City Council and other interested parties to ensure that it will be safe and practicable.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Seafront Cycle Route Gets Green Light
Seafront Cycle Route Gets Green Light

item.title: Strategic Cycle Routes in Portsmouth
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_385" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Strategic Cycle Routes"][/caption] In conjunction with the CTC, Portsmouth Cycle Forum has produced a detailed assessment of the current strategic cycle routes in and out of Portsmouth. The document provides an objective user's view of the key cycle routes in to and out of Portsmouth. It assesses their safety, their usability by all types of cyclist and how well they meet the Department for Transport (DfT) and Portsmouth City Council (PCC) aspirations for cycle infrastructure. PCC aspires to produce a cycle network interconnecting all locations in the city - good quality arterial routes in and out of the city are an essential element of any such network. This document therefore provides a baseline to assist planning and development of Portsmouth's cycle network. The document is split into two sections - the main body which presents an overview and assessment of each route and appendices which provide detailed analysis of each route. Both are available for download:
  • Commentary on Strategic Cycle Routes in Portsmouth - Main Body (0.5 MB PDF)
  • Commentary on Strategic Cycle Routes in Portsmouth- Appendices (5.5 MB PDF)

item.title: Family Christmas Cycle Ride
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_377" align="alignleft" width="117" caption="Langstone Harbour Ride"][/caption] Eleven hardy cyclists (including two under-fives) braved the stormy conditions for the Cycle Forum's first ever Christmas cycle ride on Sunday 6 December. The rain was falling at 9am, but an hour later the clouds dispersed and the sun shone allownig us to take the scenic, and largely off-road, route. Following the City Council's guide 'Circular Ride Around Langstone Harbour', we travelled from Eastney in a clockwise direction taking in the delights of the Eastern Road cycleway, the Farlington to Broadmarsh cycle route (alongside the A27), then the Hayling Billy route along the old railway line. With only one cycle casualty (a puncture), we arrived at the Ferry Boat Inn on Hayling Island and pursuaded the ferryman to make a special journey back to Portsmouth. The distance travelled was approximately 15 miles / 21 km.

item.title: Free Bicycle Marking in Portsmouth
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_71" align="alignleft" width="252" caption="Stamp out bike theft!"][/caption] Hampshire Police are offering free 'Cycle Marking' sessions in Commercial Road, Portsmouth between 10am and 4pm on 19th January, 17th February and 17th March. There have been 1361 cycles stolen in the city between January and October (that's 35 per week!) and one of the biggest challenges facing the police is the fact that they are unable to identify the rightful owners once a bike is found. Marking your beloved will much increase the chance of getting it back from the Police if it does disappear.

item.title: PCF to Host CTC/Cyclenation Conference
item.dc:creator: pcf_webmaster
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_446" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Portland Building, University of Portsmouth"][/caption] Portsmouth Cycle Forum with the Cycle Touring Club and Cyclenation are pleased to announce that Portsmouth is to host the CTC/Cyclenation Cycle Campaign Conference, on 17th April 2010. The conference will take place in the heart of Portsmouth that could be one of UKs most inspiring cycling cities. Sharing skills, knowledge and cycling best practise in UK is the core of the Portsmouth conference programme. John Holland, Chairman of Portsmouth Cycle Forum said CTC / Cyclenation host Cycle Campaign Conferences around the country. Portsmouth Cycle Forum now invites participants from all over the UK to the 2010 event in Portsmouth." Booking for the conference will open in early February via the conference website.

item.title: Local Transport Plan 3
item.dc:creator: jas
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_463" align="alignleft" width="150" caption="Seafront Cycling"][/caption] Local transport plans are an important part of transport planning in England. Strategic transport authorities (in our case Portsmouth City Council) are expected to prepare them as forward-looking plans and present them to the Department for Transport (DfT). The current Local Transport Plan (LTP2) is due to end in 2011 and LTP3 is in preparation. LTP3 is potentially a very long lived plan (possibly in excess of 15 years) and it is therefore essential that we get cycling into the heart of the plan from the outset. With this in mind PCF members and CTC Right-to-Ride reps Hilary Reed and Jon Spencer met with the PCC LTP3 team today. As a result PCC has committed to engage with the cycle forum throughout the creation of LTP3. CTC Cycle Digest 60 focussing on LTP 3 is available here. The CTC guide to cycle friendly local transport can be downloaded here.

item.title: Open Meeting
item.dc:creator: jas
